Do you know those times when you've just finished with a game and you really don't know what to play, nothing really stands out, there's a few games you'd like to try but they're way too expensive, there's a few you have halfway but don't feel like going back to, and you just start browsing your vast, VAST library of Steam trash for something that you might have left relatively untouched for one reason or the other in a desperate attempt to avoid throwing more money into the always hungry maw of procrastination? Even if you somehow never have despite stumbling into the steam page of a VERY cheap 2016 game, I'm pretty sure you could probably relate to it.

I bought this game while it was still in Early Access, probably on the suggestion of a group of people I had played the first HTS game with. Our playthrough obviously didn't make it very far, and so this game sat, untouched and undisturbed on my game collection, until at the start of this very unproductive weekend, and what can I say, I guess it's just what I was in the mood for, even though looking back on it, I don't think it's a very good game.

HTS2 is a very straightforward third person action-survival game split between a big hub map where the player can collect resources, build a base and craft gear and items, and where they will speak with quest-givers who will send them on self-contained, predefined missions. Complete these missions, and you will earn materials to upgrade your base and craft new items with, and experience points that can be put towards an (extremely convoluted) level-up system, as well as advancing their respective questlines. Missions can be repeated as many times as desired, and the only penalty for dying, as far as I'm aware, is loss of experience points and some minutes of player time. I'm assuming there's some kind of failure state at some point, but I have personally not experienced it, because overall, the game is pretty easy.

To be honest, HTS2's difficulty and progression are weird. First off, the way mission difficulty is handled is beautifully simple to the point of I'm conflicted on whether to call it genius or lazy. Missions have a minimum required level, but when accepting them, they will scale to the player's for purposes of enemy type and level. The player can choose to further modify the mission's level, by simply having the choice to raise or lower it by 5, meaning that if a mission is level 10 but I'm 20, I will be able to change it to be between level 15 and 25. Rewards are the same, loot is the same (not sure about enemy drops), but the total exp points received for that mission will have a multiplier based off the difference between the minimum and the level at which it is played. In my previous example, that would mean a multiplier of between 5x and 15x from the base exp reward.

Experience points are spent through a baroque triple-layered system: First, you need to spend points on your camp level. This basically governs your progress through the game, which buildings you get access to, the cap of your [i]individual[/i] building levels, as well as your character's. Then, you will spend exp points into your character level, which in turn controls the enemy's, and the skill levels you get access you, *AND THEN* you'll spend exp points into upgrading skills like more damage, more sprint speed, etc. Buildings are upgraded by materials, which gives access to new gear and items. There are a few melee weapons which I have barely used, and 6 main categories of ranged weapons: pistols, revolvers, rifles, smgs, bows and crossbows for which you'll get access to direct upgrades to craft, as well as accessories that can be installed through a customization menu. Armors seem more like sidegrades, less like options and more "this is what you'll wear for the next 10 levels". Effectiveness is hard to gauge from the tons of stats provided, and some upgrades sometimes aren't obvious looking at the numbers, while others carry enormous tradeoffs that are not worth it. Overall the game feels like it was built with a much bigger idea in mind and that it eventually had to be cut down, but from what there is, I would say it tries very commendably to make all gear viable and give each tool its purpose, although there is little to no reason to just stick with bows through the entirety of the game.

Despite the absolute showers of exp you can receive, progression through the game is mainly dragged down by resources. I imagine this game was built with multiplayer in the forefront, with several players contributing to its construction, and the materials that your base will require to stay up to date will vastly outstrip what you will receive through missions. This means that at some point you will invariably need to repeat some, and while this is pretty painless, it's not great. The game will include a glossary of items that you can access you see the three missions you've received the most of in as a quick guide to what to run if you want this, which is a very nice touch, though.

The game, while not looking amazing, holds up in a very xbox 360 arcade kind of way. The textures look mostly drab and ugly, but the animations are lovely, the models are crisp, the camera doesn't get in the way, and when it's not at night and/or raining (which is a depressingly large chunk of the time I spent playing), the game looks very decent. It also controls great, too, and in gamepad the scheme is very well though out and implemented. Menu navigation is a pain in the ass, but in general menus in this game are the counterpoint to the bright spots in other areas of the game. They are boring, straighfrorward, cluttery and clunky. Functional, but barely a passing grade.

All of this out of the way through, the game provides a steady stream of missions that just basically serve as an excuse to go from A to B, kill all zombies in between and loot all the lootables you can find. Come back to camp, drop everything off, craft a little, go see what's the next mission, and what can I say, it works mesmerizingly well and will put you in that sort of trance like state only a steady stream of fast food-like sludge pumped directly into your brain can do. It's not great, it's not amazing, but it works and it's just the right amount of interesting and satisfying to keep you pushing for the next mission, and the next level. The enemy variety, although not crazy, keeps throwing you new enemies, and while the random spawning will sometimes upset the flow of a level as they were originally designed (sometimes leaving entire swathes of level basically empty and useless), missions are varied in terms of objectives and overall design, although some of them will become repetitive pretty soon due to the similar layouts, but they are quick and brisk and much like the rest of the product it's [i]just competent enough[/i] to keep your attention.

There is a surprisingly large amount of stuff I'd like to talk about regarding this game when considering how mediocre it is considered as a whole. It's got a lot of quirks and design decisions that hint a lot of care went into its design, and it's a game that has very very solid fundamentals and that went for far higher than it should have cared for. You'll see a lot of reviews listing negatives and I'll probably agree with every single one of them. But at the end of the day I'd be lying if I didn't say I haven't enjoyed the time I've spent with it and that, if you get it at a good price, this is a heaping greasy awful delicious ladleful of gaming comfort food.

7/10.

Honestly, I wish I could recommend this game, now that the full DLC pack is on sale.  It has so much potential, but by level 16, I can honestly say that HtS2 is frustrating in some curious ways that I cannot really get around.

First, off, my first 10 levels were a total blast.  Unfortunately, this is due to the fact that I was shamelessly spoiled with DLC content that actually made the game faster and funner than it actually is in reality.

I have never seen a game that essentially punishes you by leveling ever before.  The zombies, the same ones you see at level 1, become more and more terrifying as you level and they essentially out pace your skills and gear (choice of ... can we say play style?) until you can get past the hump levels where new unlocks let you get the next upgrade of your weapon choices.  

Sure, you can keep swapping between weapon types, favoring the weapon that just simply does the most damage at that level, but that defeats the point of having different types of weapons.  I wanted to use fast melee weapons and assault rifles.  Well, mostly, I got hooked on the play style of those weapons because I got the DLC packs in the bundle and was rewarded with some lovely swords and a great assault rifle.  Soon enough, I had to switch the melee out to slow, clunky enormous hammer like objects just to get the job done.  

Then ... I am not sure when ... my assault rifle went from 1 unaimed shot kills to 2 to 3 ... and aimed shots have now reached two head shots to kill the same stupid zombies I was shooting from day 1.  I had totally enjoyed the hell out of the first 10 levels due to the DLC content, but it turns out, I was playing a drastically skewed version of those levels due to this gear.  Now, I wouldn't normally complain, but at level 16, with all of the skills upgraded and the best assault rifle I can have (same one since level 1) it takes more bullets and more running around in circles than ever before to do ... THE EXACT SAME THING.  

Really uncertain why they couldn't smooth out the progression a little better on gear upgrades and/or make the zombies level at a little more in line with your own progression of skill/gear.  I am terrified of levels 17-20, then, supposedly, at that point I can make a new assualt rifle ... but good grief, just gathering supplies for those three levels will seriously suck ... mostly (see below).

Pro tip ... keep a local game with a lower level camp so you can farm the basics on the main map, which will stay at your camp level, not your character level.  This is of course ridiculous ... you shouldn't have to feel like swapping to another game to gather some freaking wood and the even more elusive braided rope (my own personal hell grind).  To overcome the obvious problem of being a mule, you can at least store crap in your bunker chest and have that crap follow you between your camps ... this probably being one of the obvious reasons why that is true.

To facilitate your grind, you can lower the difficulty level of quests (unless they started at your level), and well, you would be insane not to ... otherwise gathering some sheet metal will take serious fighting every time.

And honestly, this is the only time I really enjoy the game, when the quest is a few levels below me, because it makes killing the hordes of zombies actually FUN, rather than a repeating struggle.

Which leads to the next complaint.  Can we say grind grind grind grind grind grind grind grind grind.  You will run all over the main map to gather wood, plants, and rope (... wtf) a billion times.  It is not a big map.  It gets old ... real fast.  You will also play 1/4 - 1/3 of the missions over and over until you want to cry ... just to get enough junk to upgrade your armory in hopes of getting a weapon upgrade to stem the ever growing pain of the zombies that level better than you do (and then to find that there is nothing useful in the next 3 building upgrades that you grinded your brains out for).

I guess it is worth mentioning here that you will spend countless hours running through buildings and unlocking doors (which takes time) finding absolutely nothing ... which really starts to get on your nerves when you have run through a thousand empty rooms.

Add to this the senseless deaths that can suddenly happen from a couple, semi-glitchy zombie deer that will decide to charge and gore you the moment you are running in circles to shoot the ever more intense "basic" zombies.

And the UI just feels ... clunky.  I am already simply exhausted with there being no keymap to transfer ALL of an item to your trunk (which you do constantly).  You drag, drop, and then move back to modal window and click OK ... that last part makes this a tremendous chore when you have heaps of stuff.  Let's not even go wild here and suggest that there be a transfer ALL "other" inventory into trunk ... or the awkwardness of the space bar being your sprint ...

And speaking of sprinting ... walking in the game is utterly slow and painful, but sprint costs you stamina (which is a minor problem as you progress), but sprinting will cause you to also jump onto and over things ... making sprinting around the game, especially inside cities, somewhat obnoxious as you are constantly running over beds and furniture (and waiting for the associated graphics to complete) and often accidentally going over a balcony when sprinting along the decks of buildings.

It would be amazing to have an actual JUMP action that did those things (console nerf?) ... I know, crazy, right?  Games have been doing jumping for a long time ... it is awesome stuff and keeps your ACTION game action feeling.  Who the heck wants to watch your character slowly lumber up onto a bed (that you hit by accident while sprinting through another empty room) ... and then not even be able to jump on it!

The graphics are very good, but there simply aren't enough of them ... all around.  More character customization would be nice, along with just more gear in general (for both progression smoothing and vanity slots).  Less re-use of the same basic map designs and elements across the types of maps would be awesome, (city, cementary, woodlands, farm ... that is it by level 16).

This game is really close to being more fun than not ... really really close, but it is just a repeating time sink that makes you cringe every damn time you level!?!?!?  I understand that some people are OK with the grinds and the challenge that the game presents, but I honestly think most people perfer to play a game where they don't get punished by leveling for 75% of the levels and want "trash" mobs to be "trash" mobs ... not suddenly twice as many bullets to kill and run faster than a rabbit on crack!

Essentially, you play the same game, over and over and over and over in a way that puts Diablo franchise to absolute shame in content re-use.

As a fan of How To Survive 1, I am enjoying this sequel.  There are quite a few changes from the first game.  Less linear play, more of an open world feel that you can explore with tons of quest-dungeons you can do with several NPCs along the way, and repeat if you feel the need to.  The food and water system can make it incredibly difficult when you first start, until you realize there is an abundance of food on the map when you figure out where to look (it's not nearly as bad as some make it out as far as food availability, exploring the camp map after the first 2 quests can prove very fruitful early on).  I wouldn't say HTS2 is harder than HTS1, not by a long shot, but you can adjust some of the difficulty by choosing to do quest dungeons 5 levels above you and there is far more to do.  Some weapons can be a bit OP with the right combination of ammunition.  And lots of crafting/camp building to occupy your time.  

So what are the cons?  There are a couple for me that stand out like a sore thumb.

First and foremost, no camera rotation, for the life of me I don't understand anyone making a top-down perspective game doesn't think camera rotation is mandatory.  This creates many scenarios where you have a very short angle on your field of vision, unless you happen to be moving in a direction where the camera is following your back.  These guys aught to be flogged for this.  I have never played a top-down sandbox without the ability to do so.  

Inability to pause single player game.  This is pretty silly, you cannot step away from the game without either quitting to the main menu or suspending the process in your resource monitor.  If you do, you continue to consume food and water and risk the chance of being attacked.  Now if you are just hanging around in camp, that's fine, you can just quit to the menu then restart, nothing is lost.  However if you are in the middle of a quest/dungeon mission, you will lose your progress and need to start over.   Really guys, no pause?  

Resources are really plentiful, dare I say too plentiful.  That and quest replayability makes it fairly easy to get whatever you need with a very little bit of elbow grease.  Ammunition is pretty easy to manufacture once you have a few levels on your armory.  Arrows are reuseable if you collect them.  You should never struggle for resources in this game.  This lends itself to making the game easier than it should be.  

But overall, I think it has some decent replayability.  And Kovac, as always, makes for great apocalyptian company.  It's still a fun zombie RPG hack and slash, albeit not as challenging as it could be.  And if you've ever wanted a bow that shoots like a semi-automatic, this is it.  Pick up the dynamite DLC too.  Also important to note: To play in fullscreen (as you will not see the option) open the launch configuration and select it there before starting the game.

Overall an ok game, it has a lot of fun elements but also a lot of missed opportunities.  Overall a 6.5/10, definitely worth it when it's on sale.  I wouldn't recomend buying it at full price and would skip it if you are bord of "survival lite" zombie games.

TL:DR: basic graphics, repetative environments and quests, offset but decently fun progression and gameplay.  Not a GOTY contender by any stretch of the imagination but worth a few bucks if you like survival lite, and/or isometric games.

Graphics: 4/10: isometric games generally are lower end graphics wise but this game is rather basic in this area. Maps are repetetive, animations are limited.  Areas start to feel extremely similar to one another pretty quickly.  Some effort is made to proved various "biomes" like forest, swamp, city etc but ultimately it's not enough and they HEAVILY reuse building interiors.  

Sound: 5.5/10: decent sounds convey the bleak apocalyptic setting well enough.  Different enemies have different sound effects that allow you to identify them.  The music gets repetetive.

Gameplay: 6/10: the isometric view and combat take a bit to get used to but function well enough once you figure it out.  

Survival/crafting: 6/10: it's survival and crafting "lite" which is fine by me.  People in search of a "hardcore" survival game will probably be dissapointed as it just uses a basic thirst/hunger system and once you get a few levels you will always have plenty of food and drink with no concerns over starvation.  It's also a casual approach as death is just a minor xp penalty and respawn.  I haven't played the harder difficulties so there may be some value there for people  in search of a more "hardcore" game.

Overall though the missed opportunities are what make this game more of a "buy it on sale" affair.  A few things that would have made the game better:

- Melee is too limited and over simplified: later in the game you run into more dangerous enemies that charge at you and can knock you down/deal large damage at close range.  There's also a huge amount of exploding enemies that must be killed from range.  Some sort of "double tab space bar to dive to one side + left mouse click to quickly attack" combo move would have made melee a lot more viable in the later game.  

also some sort of blocking for those high dps close range enemies would have helped.  Right click aims ranged, if it blocked in melee (with a specific timing needed to work that takes skill) would have been awesome. Due to these shortcomings of the overly simplified melee, you need to rely on ranged for a lot of situations.  maybe melee alone is viable but I don't see it especially due to the exploding enemies and lack of good block/dodge.

- crazy powerful enemies that don't make sense: one of the most devastating mid game enemies is an infected bunny.  They really could have done better, like use infected bears, lions, something.  but an infected bunny?  C'mon devs, your better than that :P

- complete lack of stealth: this might be controversial from those who think it would trivialize the difficulty and perhaps thats true but if there was some sort of risk/reward stealth gameplay option that would have been interesting.  Perhaps you need to use special armor that makes you more vulnerable as a trade off but having stealth in the game would at least open up more gameplay variety

- more variety: the "holiday" zones like mardi gras, christmax, etc are a nice fund disctraction with different music and visuals but these are too few and too far in between to break up the monotony of otherwise similar quests in areas that look/feel the same to one another.

- confusing mats: you need materials to upgrade your camp and gear but the game only sometimes makes it easy to actually find what you need.  A quest log that you can access whenever you want that breaks down both the mats you've found in the actual quest in the past as well as the quest rewards would make it a lot easier to remember where to get that metal grate or whatever when you need it.

- a way to place exactly 1 entrance to the bunker on the map: you make your camp in a fortified spot but depending on where you set up you then need to run to a bunker entrance to then fast travel elsewhere in the world.  Having to make that run over and over and over doesn't really add any value to the game.  Sure you can build your camp next to an entrance but really letting the player build their own entrace would have been a great QOL upgrade.

- confusing progression: I'm actually a bit conflicted on this because I do feel modern games hold players hands too much but in any event, the game progresssion isn't always very linear or sensical.  One example, you run into an "infected turtle" that is literally invincible unless you have the right ammunition to kill it.  The game does nothing to warn you about this or prepare you for it, you just start trunning into turtles at some point depending on your level and if you don't have the right ammo you can't kill it and can only run away.  Perhaps at least some sort of hint earlier in the game that "certain types of ammo can pierce armor really well" would have at least given the player fair warning that a) there are armored enemies in the game and that b) you need to upgrade your ammo to deal with them would have at least given fair warning.

- story: so far the game is basically: there are zombies, you need to survive.  very basic, next to 0 character development or story arc.  Maybe it changes later on but a story or character driven game this is not.  an interesting plot would only help make this a better game.

- weapon diversity: there's very clear "best" weapons as you progress that make all other weapons in that category useless.  A good game will design weapons that fill different niches. so maybe there's a fast attack weapon that can be "top tier" if you max out your desterity but that sucks if you are all strength.  This game doesn't allow for that level of customization, only rewarding using specific top end weapons for any given category.  creating a good light, medium, and heavy version of melee weapons with surporting skills for each would have allowed players more agency in how they build and play their survivor.

- Ultra linear progression: what I mean is, there's always 1 bow, rifle, melee weapon etc. that will 1 shot most basic zombies as you progress.  If you don't upgrade your weapons and ammo, the game seems to get harder because that weapon will start to take more and more shots to kill off basic enemies even if you level up your survivors skills. 

But it's not really getting harder because the very instant you craft the new "best" weapon and new "best" ammo and level up the appropriate skill you are suddenly back to the same power level as before.  This stagnant power level makes the game feel the same from beginning to end: sure I'm levelling up my skills but it's only so that I can keep pace with the enemies, I can never gain any ground.  Your character feels exactly as powerful at level 25 as it did at level 1.  Just keep your character skilled up in 1 primary weapon and maybe (but not necessarily) 1 secondary weapon and always make the new version as your advance and your set.

Overall I'm closing in on 30 hours as I type this and will probably play until I hit max level and see if there's more of a story later on.

How would you classify this game? Personally, I'd call it an open world sandbox survival RPG, but I'm not completely sure if that'd be entirely accurate. Truth is, it has a combination of survival, sandbox RPG, and Diablo-esque action RPG all in one. That is to say that you can pretty much do whatever you like in your camp and during quests, you create and build up a character through a light RPG skill system and as fun as the quests can be, they can also be a bit grindy as aRPGs are. Throughout it all, you have to be careful to watch your food and water rates. Moreover, it doesn't take much to get killed but all weapons and gear have strategy to them which help you even the odds a bit. This is all tied together by an impeccable sense of atmosphere, yet it's measured by an equal sense of humor as well.

In general, How to Survive 2 is a very, very fun game when you play it more like a simulator. If you go in expecting massive, epic missions every time, or the ability to customize a character's looks or skills down to the finest detail, you'll be disappointed. Instead, when you play it more like a simulator, it feels a lot more enjoyable. This enjoyment is multiplied by the multiplayer feature. Joining up with other players is very fun, especially during the missions. I've played the game with a friend before and we took on a nighttime mission into a town. The whole way, it was downright creepy because we'd hear the groans and growls of zombies that we couldn't see, so we knew we needed to keep an eye out but not lose sight of the goal in the mission. Eventually, we ran into a huge horde of zombies and got split up. I ran toward a chokepoint within a decaying building where I was able to split off the horde between a doorway on one end and a fallen wall on the other. I was able to eliminate the ones coming through the door with my pistol so that by the time the others came through the wall, I could focus on them alone. Eventually, this enabled me to reunite with my friend. We succeeded at completing the mission but not after several massive close calls. This is just one example of some of the tactics and natural scenarios that play out in this game, especially with multiplayer.

The story itself is really rudimentary but that's because this isn't a narrative RPG. It serves more to help you learn the game and build yourself up. As I mentioned prior, it has a fantastic sense of atmosphere but it's balanced by a Borderlands-esque humor during some of the story missions. It's passable but again, don't come in expecting Fallout.

The world is open, but not seamless. You have your basic overworld where you can find random enemies and resources and that's the area that you build your base. There are a lot of options in that regard, as the world consists of forest areas, swampy areas, cabins, trains, clay pits and so forth. As far as environmental design goes, however, the missions are where the game really shines. The atmosphere goes from good to great during most missions and because of the randomized nature of them, each one of them feels mysterious and you get a sense of apocalyptic adventure when exploring these maps. From standard forest hunting trips to supply runs in ruined cities to a mission at an overrun farm, it all gives me the same vibes I got the first time I played Telltale's The Walking Dead: Season 1 and even some of the same vibes I got from watching the show. This is the game to play if you want to live out your Walking Dead action fantasies and you can roleplay if you have friends that want to play that way, but if you want something where you can create a character with a story and proper choice-and-consequence, this isn't the game for that. I'd recommend the Telltale Walking Dead games or the Fallout series for that sort of gameplay (you can even get a mod for Fallout 4 that enables a zombie apocalypse).

Overall, I do recommend this game. It can be extremely fun but you need to go in with realistic and informed expectations. Again, don't expect a groundbreaking story with choice and consequence, a seamless open world and loads of detail. It's a pretty good newbie-friendly and semi-lightweight alternative to other survival games like DayZ or Fallout 76.

It feels more close to some diablo-like arpg with crafting and no special abilities than a more eclectic survival action that was the original.
